SINGAPORE'S FINANCIAL POSITION
(Statement by the Minister for Finance)


2.32 p.m.

    The Minister for Finance (Dr Goh Keng Swee): Mr Speaker, Sir, I wish to report to the Assembly on certain aspects of our financial position.

    When we assumed office, we made a detailed investigation of the finances of the country. The Government has reported that a deficit of $14 million has to be disposed of. The sum itself is not very large but what was of greater import is that for some time past current expenditure had been financed out of the reserves of the country. This points to a basic imbalance between revenue and expenditure which needs looking into.

    The General Revenue balance now stands at about three months' revenue. It is therefore a matter of common prudence that the revenue balance shall not be permitted to go much below this limit unless new sources of liquidity are readily available. It has therefore been necessary to take a number of steps some of which have been severe in character.

    The Government has frozen all vacancies arising in the establishment without making a distinction as to the reasons for such vacancies, whether they arise from retirement or resignation, or whether they are newly created posts. Special Expenditure has also been frozen so that a careful scrutiny can be made to weed out items which are not absolutely necessary. A Cabinet committee was formed, consisting of the Prime Minister as Chairman, and the Deputy Prime Minister and myself as the other members. We have gone through applications from Ministries and departments and have set up the most stringent standards.

    Recently all Ministers have been asked to scrutinise the state of the vote and to report on what economies are possible. This whole process of freezing and vetting of expenditure constitutes a major operation. As a result, substantial economies have been effected and the total amount of reduction has reached the figure of $25.7 million. Of this, $20.1

Column: 527

million were reductions in the Ordinary Estimates and $5.6 million were savings in the Development Estimates. This is a considerable achievement and has been made possible through the co-operation of all departments of Government.

    I wish to pay a special tribute to senior Treasury officials who have had to put in long and punishing hours of work in the course of this exercise. I also want to acknowledge the full-hearted support of my colleagues in this economy drive. My colleagues and I work as a team and it is because we work as a team that it has been possible to reduce the estimated expenditure by this substantial amount.

    It will be idle to pretend, however, that the slashes in the economy drive of this magnitude can be brought out painlessly. Everyone is aware of the pained reaction to the cuts in variable allowances. Because of the freeze on vacancies, many Ministries have to work short-handed and this means that everyone works harder. Then many of the schemes which have been entered in the Estimates after years of tussle with the Treasury have now to be jettisoned or at least postponed.

    The operation has not been a painless one but it is necessary, in the interest of financial solvency, that one sets one's face sternly against the cries of anguish coming from the stricken.

    I am now in the happy position to report to the Assembly that, as a result of our exertions, the finances of the Government have now attained a healthier state. Before I present the facts and figures, there is one point to which I wish to draw attention. And this is that not only had authorised expenditure exceeded estimated revenue by a substantial amount when we took office but there were signs that certain items of revenue had not been keeping up with the estimated levels. In particular, the tobacco revenue has declined very seriously as compared with the amount estimated. This has increased both the difficulties of balancing the Budget and

the urgency to do so. I show in summary form how the finances of the Government now stand. The figures are given in Table 1* which have been distributed to Members.

    The general position is that we are now faced with a small deficit of $2.9 million. This is a comparatively small sum. It is likely that we shall end the year on an even keel. There may be need for additional expenditure in respect of claims already submitted by Ministries and which are under examination. As against this, it is possible that we may tap new sources of revenue. As stated in the policy speech of the Yang di-Pertuan Negara, this Government will not consider revenue increases until all possible economy measures have first been applied. We have now reached this stage and are free to consider proposals to increase revenue.

    When I said before that we shall probably "balance" the Budget, I used the word in reference to the accounting practice adopted in the past. It had been the practice for some time to finance part of the development by depleting reserve funds. In 1959, this practice has continued in the Estimates. Members will note in Section B 3 (iv) in the first Table that $18.5 million is to be transferred from the General Revenue balance to the Development Budget. As I said earlier, we should not allow the General Revenue balance to fall much below its present level and it will therefore be necessary to finance part of the Development Expenditure by loans. The Government has already announced its intention to float two loans of different maturities.

    In this assessment of the financial position of the country, I must therefore make some reference to the state of the public debt and the accumulation of funds which the Government and various statutory bodies under its direction hold locally and abroad.

Column: 529



    So far as the Government is concerned, the public debt has been very small. This has its virtues. At the same time, it must be borne in mind that there is no merit in not borrowing money from the public if this means retarding essential development schemes and services which are necessary to the growth of the economy. More especially where public savings are available, it is foolish to deny these sound opportunities for investment in this country - investments which would promote further expansion in various sectors of the economy.

    So far as this Government itself is concerned, the position is that the total public debt stands at $115 million. Of this, sinking funds have been accumulated which amount to about $75 million. There is therefore a net public debt of $40 million or some $25 per head of population. There are very few governments which have a public debt as low as this. Further, we must take into account the various reserve funds which the Government has accumulated in the various funds and the loans advanced to statutory bodies. These latter total some $190 million of which $172 million are still outstanding. The Government itself emerges as an overall creditor.

    To assess the financial standing of the country as a whole, it is necessary to take into account not only the resources of the central government but those of the statutory bodies. I give the total investments held in funds under the control of the central government and its statutory bodies. The details appear in Table 3** which has been distributed to Members.

    ** Appendix III, cols. 631-2.
APPENDIX III(Cols 0631-0632)


    The total value of all these funds comes to $417.6 million. Of this, $144.6 million are accumulated in local investments. The balance of $273 million is invested abroad. The breakdown of the overseas investments of Government and statutory bodies is illuminating and the figures are given in Table 4++. The picture which emerges is an extraordinary one. While we in Singapore have always

APPENDIX IV(Cols 0631-0632)


Column: 530

cried aloud for the entry of foreign capital, we have been unaware that we have enormous sums of money invested abroad for the development of countries most of which are far wealthier than us. If we take into account private Singapore investments abroad, the value of our total foreign investments will be even much greater. The latest estimate in respect of banks, places the net assets of Singapore banks held in foreign countries at $325 million. In addition, we have taken into account investments abroad by insurance firms operating in Singapore. There are also foreign investments by companies and private individuals resident in Singapore. The figures for all these are not readily available.

    The above account of our investments abroad does not take into consideration the currency Reserve Funds. These funds, of course, do not belong solely to Singapore. We are only one of the participating members of the agreement establishing the Currency Board, the Federation of Malaya, North Borneo, Sarawak, and Brunei being the other parties.

    The currency reserves are considerable, the latest figure being $1,110 million. All these are invested abroad. The future of the Currency Agreement is under discussion between the participating countries, and I do not wish to say more about this. I am not saying that there is any need to take precipitate action to withdraw these funds abroad for investment in Singapore. There are advantages in holding investments abroad. From the Government point of View, funds invested in London have the great advantage of liquidity. No doubt similar considerations have led to investment of bank balances in London. These bank balances are primarily used as a Reserve Balance in the financing of our foreign trade, and, as such, serve a valuable purpose. Considering that Singapore's imports and exports totalled $6,880 million in 1958, there is no ground for believing that these bank balances held abroad are excessive.

Column: 531



    I make this brief review of Singapore's overseas balances in order to underline two points. The first is that, as a great trading centre, we are a part of the world economy, and have important financial and economic links in many parts of the world. Our continued prosperity depends on strengthening these links, and if we disrupt these links, we do so at our own peril. The second point is that we have invested large sums abroad. In return, there has been a substantial investment of foreign capital in our country, though the totals have not been reliably computed. It is almost certain that after taking these into account, we emerge very much on the credit side.

    Since the end of World War II, it has become fashionable among the modern industrial nations of the world to speak of the need to assist under-developed regions, especially by way of capital investment. But in Singapore the relationship is exactly the reverse of what has now come to be accepted as normal. I do hope that when we have occasion to ask for loans from abroad, we shall not be treated as poor relatives in quest for assistance, for our moral position in this is surely very strong.

    The Chairman: Fourth Supplementary Estimates of Expenditure for 1959 (Paper Cmd. (New Series) 18 of 1959).

    There are amendments. The first is on Head 7, Chief Minister/Prime Minister, in the name of the Member for Farrer Park, in relation to subhead 1, item (33). This amendment, I have indicated to honourable Members, is in respect of an item similar to items under Heads 61 and 62. Therefore, for convenience, discussion on the first amendment may range over the other two amendments, in which event there will be no further debate when the other two amendments are reached. I trust that is clear.

    Head 7 -

    Mr A. P. Rajah (Farrer Park): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head 7 be reduced by $10 in respect of item (33) of subhead 1 therein.

    I am grateful to you, Mr Speaker, Sir, for making it possible for me to speak on the other heads of expenditure; it will save the House considerable time if I speak on all the three amendments at the same time.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, soon after the present Government was returned to power and soon after the Prime Minister and his ministerial colleagues had taken office, one of the first statements that he made was that it was the desire of the Government to cut down Government

Column: 534

expenditure and that it would be right and proper in those circumstances that the Ministers themselves should suffer the first cut. That was very laudable, and the Government proceeded to do it, thereby giving an indication to the public that the cost of ministerial Government certainly was going to be reduced. Let us, therefore, examine that statement in the light of events that have happened subsequently.

    We now find that requests are being made for Political Secretaries. Beyond Political Secretaries, Parliamentary Secretaries have also been appointed to Ministries, where previously Assistant Ministers had not existed. I venture to suggest, Mr Speaker, Sir, that the total costs of the Ministers together with their Parliamentary Secretaries and Political Secretaries - such as we know them - perhaps exceed the total cost of what the Ministers and the Assistant Ministers had previously drawn - when I say "previously drawn", Mr Speaker, I mean by Ministers and Assistant Ministers in the previous Government.

    This appointment of Political Secretary is something which certainly is not known to the Constitution of Singapore. Therefore, it would be interesting to find out what this appointment is. Firstly, are these posts civil service posts? That is the first question, and I would like it answered. If they are civil service posts, have these appointments already been made? If so, by whom? If they are not civil service posts, and if these appointments have already been made, who are the holders of these posts and whether these holders are members of the P.A.P. and have been given these posts merely because they have been useful to the Party in bringing them to power? And lastly, Mr Speaker, Sir, I would like to know whether there are only three Political Secretaries attached to the three Ministries set out here, namely

    Head 7 Chief Minister/Prime Minister

    Subhead 1 item (33) Personal Secretary (Political).

    Head 61 Ministry of Culture

    Subhead 1 item (3) Personal Secretary (Political), one ($1,400); one ($1,100).

For the Minister for Culture, not one, Mr Speaker, Sir, but two Political Secretaries. Under -

    Head 62 Ministry of National Development Subhead 1 item (3) Personal Secretary (Political).

I do not know whether there are other Personal Secretaries (Political) attached to the other Ministries, but these are the only posts which the House is aware of in these Estimates.

3.00 p.m.

    Another curious feature of the Personal Secretary (Political) is that, as described here, the Prime Minister carries a Personal Secretary (Political), the Minister for National Development also carries a Personal Secretary (Political), whereas the Minister for Culture carries two, one Personal Secretary (Political) at $1,400 a month, and a second Personal Secretary (Political) at $1,100 a month. If they are given the value for the posts, I suppose the gentleman who is holding the post at $1,400 must be holding the more valuable post. Perhaps the House could be told why it is necessary, if at all it is necessary, to have Political Secretaries, that the Minister for Culture should have two Personal Secretaries, and one at a rate which exceeds all the other Personal Secretaries by $300 a month.

    The Chairman: The Question is "That the sum to be allocated for Head 7 be reduced by $10 in respect of item (33) of subhead 1 therein." As indicated, the debate may range over Head 61, subhead 1, item (3) , Personal Secretary (Political), $17,500, in respect of which an amendment appears in the Supplement to the Order Paper in the name of the Member for Farrer Park:

    That the sum to be allocated for Head 61 be reduced by $10 in respect of item (3) of subhead 1.

Similarly with regard to Head 62, subhead 1, item (3).

    The Prime Minister (Mr Lee Kuan Yew): Mr Speaker, I must congratulate the Member for Farrer Park for his ingenuity in calculating the costs of the

Column: 536

present Ministries as against those of the previous Government, and coming to the brilliant conclusion that we are costing the people more. I have to disillusion him, because he forgot to include in the previous Government the officials, of which there were three, who were colleagues of the present Member for Geylang Serai. If you look under the Heads, "Chief Secretary", "Attorney-General", all under the Ministerial side, and the cost of the linen and the crockery and all the rest of it, you will find that it comes to much more than what we are costing now.

    Nevertheless, I welcome the opportunity to clarify the appointment of Personal Secretaries (Political).

    Each Minister, to assist him in the discharge of his responsibilities, has a Parliamentary Secretary, a Permanent Secretary and a Personal Secretary (Political). As has already been pointed out, the Minister for Culture, according to Cmd. Paper 18 of 1959 is carrying two Political Secretaries. I congratulate the Member for Farrer Park for his assiduous study of this Paper and for having anticipated an amendment which will be moved by the Minister for Culture to clarify the designation of one of those two posts. In fact, there is only one Personal Secretary (Political). The other, at $1,400, is not a Personal Secretary (Political). I shall not anticipate what my colleague will be saying when he moves the amendment.

    May I first delineate briefly the duties of the Parliamentary Secretary and the Personal Secretary (Political)? Everybody knows what the Permanent Secretary is supposed to do. His duties are set out in the Constitution itself.

    The Parliamentary Secretary, as the term designates, carries the burden of the Minister's parliamentary duties, and to the extent that the Minister designates or delegates, he carries the burden of the Minister's ministerial duties. The Personal Secretary (Political) has no administrative duties. He has no direct access to the Civil Service. He is a personal appointment of the Minister, and his role is really that of the

Column: 537

Minister's closest confidant on the political implications of the moves, plans and policies of the various Ministries.

    May I say that there have been three appointments, and that there will be three more in the near future. Ultimately, all the appointments will be filled.

    First, my own personal appointment. He is Mr Jek. The second is Mr Woodhull whose appointment is Personal Secretary (Political) to the Minister for Health. The third is Mr Rahim Ishak, who is Personal Secretary (Political) to the Minister for Culture. They are, Mr Speaker, Sir, our political chiefs of staff, so to speak, political backroom boys, the people who have the aptitude, the skill and touch in these matters which are of invaluable assistance, I hope, to all Ministers, to avoid the unnecessary faux pas which would otherwise fall their way if the presentation and implementation of policies were left entirely to the Civil Service.

    It follows, therefore, that they are all political appointments. I am unable to enlighten the Member on the actual procedure on these appointments. I shall leave that to my Minister for Finance, who is more acquainted with establishment matters. What it amounts to is this. This is the Minister's Personal Secretary (Political). It says what it means.

    May I say to the House that one of the problems which this Government faces - and I have said this on many previous occasions - is not only the carrying out of our plans and policies, but also the manner and method of presentation of these policies to the people of Singapore.

    Mr Jek was a former newspaper man on a Chinese newspaper. He also went to gaol for some time in 1957/1958 for alleged subversive activities. He was released, presumably because the Government discovered that the allegation of subversive activities was unfounded. He is not the type of person whom we would want to give a job to for the sake of rewarding him. If the last Government had a fraction of the skill and devotion to duty, the political know-how that these

Column: 538

types of persons have, they would not have come such miserable croppers as they did.

    These are open political appointments, and I venture to suggest that succeeding governments will find that this is a sound and healthy practice.

    Mr Speaker, let me just refer you to one instance of the kind of difficulties those people extricate us from. You will remember, Mr Speaker, that we were making arrangements for the Yang di-Pertuan Negara to deliver the first speech to this Assembly in Malay. The permanent staff was there, the skilled translators in the former P.R.O. and those you had prudently recruited beforehand. It was a difficult first task - 18 pages of translation were almost unintelligible. But Mr Rahim Ishak, who I hope will continue to give the Minister for Culture the political touch, was in the space of 24 hours able to reduce what was an unintelligible verbatim translation into one which I hope Malay Members on the other side will agree was a coherent and smooth passage from the Yang di-Pertuan Negara in the national language. He was able to do that because, amongst other things, he used to be the leader writer in the Utusan Melayu.

    The Minister for Culture (Mr S. Rajaratnam): Mr Speaker, Sir, I should like to draw the attention of the House to Head 61, subhead 1, item (3) which now reads "Personal Secretary (Political), one ($1,400); one ($1,100)."

    I am sorry if I have slightly confused the Member for Farrer Park, but I think he will have a better understanding of what all this is about if I say that this does not reflect the staffing position quite accurately. It should now read, "Publicity Liaison Secretary (Political) ($1,400), and Personal Secretary (Political) ($1,100)".

    The purpose of this new designation is to indicate more precisely the functions of one of the Secretaries. The post of Publicity Liaison Secretary (Political) is also an appointment personal to the Minister, but it involves duties and functions which are in some respects different

Column: 539

from those of Personal Secretary (Political). When the Supplementary Estimates were submitted, the post of Publicity Liaison Secretary (Political) was then designated as Personal Secretary (Political), because at that time it was not possible to define precisely the functions of many of the officials in the Ministry. As you know, Sir, the Ministry of Culture is a new Ministry. It has to be put together from scratch, and it is still today in the process of creation. It is therefore not possible to predict in detail what responsibility would fall on what officer and what function they would be required to perform. After all, Mr Speaker, there are many Government departments which have been in existence for nearly a century, and there are officials who are still not quite sure where they fit in, and what their precise tasks are. Therefore, when the Ministry of Culture, which is only about three months old, occasionally gives new designations to one officer, I do not think the Member for Farrer Park should see anything more sinister in it.

3.15 p.m.

    Now that the Ministry of Culture is more or less complete, the need for what I have termed a Publicity Liaison Secretary (Political) has become more apparent. His functions are those imposed by the very nature and structure of the Ministry of Culture. As you know, Sir, my Ministry is in charge of a variety of publicity services - radio, information, posters, films, publications and a public address system under which field officers go out every day to broadcast necessary and vital information to the public. This wide variety of publicity services have not only to be fed with suitable materials but it is also necessary that they function as a co-ordinated unit. It will therefore be one of the functions of the Publicity Liaison Secretary to see that there is such co-ordination.

    As to why my Ministry requires two appointments which are personal to the Minister, here again they are imposed by the very character, functions and structure of the Ministry of Culture. This Ministry is concerned with shaping people's ideas and mental attitudes. To

Column: 540

quote from the speech of the Yang di-Pertuan Negara, one of the functions of this Ministry will be to create "a sense of national identity among the various races in Malaya" and "to instil in our people of all races the will to be a nation". This, therefore, involves not only taking into account such things as sentiments, attitudes and reactions of people in general but also the attitudes, sentiments and reactions of the various cultural and racial groups in this country. Therefore, Sir, in the case of my Ministry, the bricks and mortar with which this Ministry works are of finer material than may be the case with some other Ministries. In a multi-racial society like ours, it is necessary for this Ministry to have people who can advise it on the political, social and cultural reactions of the various races and communities in Singapore. Therefore, one of these posts requires someone with a knowledge not only of the Chinese language but also of Chinese trends, thought and reactions and also a knowledge of (on the purely technical side) publicity methods and organisation.

    The other post requires someone with a knowledge of the Malay language and Malay thought, reactions and attitudes. In view of this, I feel, Sir, that there is every justification for having two political secretaries because they will guide this Ministry which deals mainly with ideas, attitudes and sentiments, to gauge accurately reactions to Government measures or Government programmes on the part of these communities.
